docs.lead_paragraph: This is a land that has seen its enemy, and he drinks red wine from a screwcap bottle. For this is cork country. Silvery green cork oaks dot the dry, straw-colored landscape. Factories for trimming, boiling and binding cork into bundles surround the whitewashed villages. The free-ranging hogs that yield the region's characteristic hams and sausages fatten on cork oak acorns. Corks pop from bottles of the local Alentejo wines that wash down virtually every meal. Local entrepreneurs hand out business cards with their names printed on slivers of cork.

headline.main: In Portugal, Cork Makers Just Say No To Screwcap

docs.abstract: Growing use of non-cork bottle stoppers by global wine industry is sharply opposed in Portugal, origin of more than half of $2 billion in corks produced annually; industry is centered in Alentejo region in country's south-central area; cork is produced by stripping bark from mature oak trees, with average tree yielding sufficient material to cork 4,000 bottles each harvest; each tree may be stripped once every nine years during its expected 200-year lifespan (M)
docs.snippet: This is a land that has seen its enemy, and he drinks red wine from a screwcap bottle.    For this is cork country. Silvery green cork oaks dot the dry, straw-colored landscape. Factories for trimming, boiling and binding cork into bundles surround...

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of New Jersey doctors failed to renew their licenses by a state deadline after widespread difficulties with a new licensing form, state officials and physicians' groups said today. The lapse has led doctors to temporarily lose the right to practice medicine in the state. The delay also forced physicians to cancel or postpone patient appointments and led many hospitals to turn away surgeons who had planned to perform operations after the June 30 renewal deadline, but had not yet received their new licenses.

headline.main: Problems With Forms Lead to Lapsed Doctors' Licenses

docs.abstract: New Jersey state officials and physicians' groups say that thousands of New Jersey doctors failed to renew their licenses by state deadline after widespread difficulties with new licensing form; lapse has led doctors to temporarily lose right to practice medicine in state (M)
docs.snippet: Thousands of New Jersey doctors failed to renew their licenses by a state deadline after widespread difficulties with a new licensing form, state officials and physicians' groups said today. The lapse has led doctors to temporarily lose the right to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Twice, John Garamendi has run for governor of California. Twice, he has lost. Now, nine months after winning election as the California insurance commissioner -- a job he also held in the early 1990's -- Mr. Garamendi is back on the campaign trail, this time, he says, for the cause of reform.

headline.main: California Official Campaigns Again, This Time for Insurance Overhaul

docs.abstract: California insurance commissioner John Garamendi is expected to make third run for governor after receiving wide approval for bringing attention to soaring cost of worker's compensation insurance; Garamendi is advocating standardized medical procedures and fees, use of generic drugs, creation of medical review panel and ombudsman to resolve disputes; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Twice, John Garamendi has run for governor of California. Twice, he has lost.    Now, nine months after winning election as the California insurance commissioner -- a job he also held in the early 1990's -- Mr. Garamendi is back on the campaign...

docs.lead_paragraph: California officials were meeting through the holiday weekend to try to address the state's $38 billion budget shortfall and an imminent reduction in the state's already low credit rating. Gov. Gray Davis vowed to resist a Republican budget plan that he said threatened education and public safety and said that a recall election to remove him would waste $30 million that would be better spent for pressing state needs.
docs.abstract: California officials are meeting through holiday weekend to address state's $38 billion budget gap and imminent cut in its already low credit rating; Gov Gray Davis vows to resist Republican budget plan; warns recall election to oust him would waste $30 million; defends own budget plan, which raises taxes by $8 billion and cuts $18 billion in spending; Republican plan has no tax increases; recall proponents continue to gather signatures; rating agencies say drive exacerbates fiscal woes; photo (M)
docs.snippet: California officials were meeting through the holiday weekend to try to address the state's $38 billion budget shortfall and an imminent reduction in the state's already low credit rating.    Gov. Gray Davis vowed to resist a Republican budget plan...

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER with JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a June 28 letter, a physician decries the move by the Food and Drug Administration to move one of the most widely prescribed ulcer medications, Prilosec, to over-the-counter status. He correctly points out the hazards of self-diagnosis and treatment of potentially serious conditions by laymen. I do, however, take issue with him when he ascribes the F.D.A.'s decision to pressure from big pharmaceutical companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Six months ago, political leaders around the New York City region were sounding alarms. They warned that state and local governments were facing the worst fiscal crisis since the 1930's and predicted dire budget cuts that in the eyes of many legislators would cripple services. In the end, though, New York State, New York City and New Jersey all managed to put together budgets that avoided the deepest cuts, and they paid for them with borrowing or tax increases that have yet to arouse a public outcry.

headline.main: More Taxes, A Few Cuts, But Little Pain In New Budgets

docs.abstract: All across nation, legislators have been wrestling with fiscal crises by shrinking spending or imposing taxes or some combination of both; New York State, New York City and New Jersey were able to put together budgets that avoided deepest cuts, and pay for them with borrowing or tax increases that have yet to arouse public outcry; in Connecticut, Gov John Rowland and legislature are at impasse; while many taxpayers may feel some sense of relief, it is only matter of time before public realizes that there are more deficits looming (M)
docs.snippet: Six months ago, political leaders around the New York City region were sounding alarms. They warned that state and local governments were facing the worst fiscal crisis since the 1930's and predicted dire budget cuts that in the eyes of many...

docs.lead_paragraph: After a troubled marriage and a long separation, two of New York's premier academic medical centers, New York University and Mount Sinai, are moving toward outright divorce. But splitting up could prove just as tricky as merging. The hospitals' serious money problems present obstacles to dissolving the financial ties that still bind them, and officials say a final division probably remains years away.

headline.main: For Hospitals Seeking Split, Debt Is Glue

docs.abstract: Serious money problems present roadblock to New York University and Mount Sinai, premier academic medical centers who are eager to sever their connection; when institutions merged in 1998, they combined debts, which total about $670 million, but now they appear too weak to be able to redivide debt, which would mean refinancing; series of credit downgrades have left entity at highest junk-bond status, making refinancing on its own prohibitively expensive; other options discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Molina Healthcare became the latest sign of a rebound for the initial public offering market, rising sharply in initial trading yesterday. Shares of Molina, a managed care company, closed at $20 on the New York Stock Exchange, up 14 percent from the offering price of $17.50 a share.

headline.main: Good Debut for Stock Suggests Rebound for Initial Offerings

docs.abstract: Molina Healthcare's shares close at $20, up 14 percent from initial public offering price of $17.50 a share (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST tournament caddies are invisible. Most golf spectators are watching the pro swinging the club, whether it's Tiger Woods or Annika Sorenstam, not the caddie with all those clubs in that big bag. But over the last quarter of a century, one caddie was often more visible than most, primarily because of the golfer he worked for, but also because he was more personable, more friendly than most.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; He's Carrying Sport's Most Human Story

docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column discusses parternship between golfer Tom Watson and caddie Bruce Edwards, who is inflicted with Lou Gehrig's disease, or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about plans by Abbott Laboratories to settle an investigation into its sales practices misspelled the name of its partner in a joint venture, TAP Pharmaceutical Products, which earlier settled accusations related to the marketing of a cancer drug. It is Takeda Chemical Industries, not Tadeka.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 27 article on plans by Abbott Laboratories to settle investigation into its sales practices, regarding name of its partner cited in article
